description.narrative: Assistance to the National Communal Service Market Regulation Comission for district heating regulatory reform support programm.

Insatsen består av ett stöd till Världsbanken för en kapacitetsutvecklingsinsats till Ukrainas regulator/myndighet som ansvarar för prissättning av fjärrvärme. Denna myndighet är ny och har fått mandatet att införa de beslutade reformerna kring prissättningen. Dock har myndigheten inte full kapacitet eller erfarenhet av dessa reformer. De har därför vänt sig till Världsbanken med ett förslag på kapacitetsutveckling och stöd.

The project development objective is to assist National Commission for State Energy and Public Utilities Regulation (NEURC) with transitioning from “cost plus” to “incentive-based” district heating tariff regulation.

description.narrative: The project activity period has expired on the 2017-12-31. By that date the progress towards the intended result, or "project development objective" (PDO) in the World Bank terminology, can be assessed as unsatisfactory. Achievements under the target of assistance with development and adoption of the new transitional tariff setting methodology and key regulatory documents covering the transition to incentive-based regulation are assessed as Low. Under the project draft key regulatory documents were developed by the consultant company (Suez-Safage or Consultant for short, the company was procured by the NEURC under the supervision of the World Bank) and accepted by NEURC, including the guidelines for regulatory audits, procedures and regulations on the treatment of the investment component of expenses in tariffs, accounting and reporting forms as well as templates for standard public contracts for heat and hot water supply. The Consultant also developed draft transitional tariff setting methodology for heat production, transmission and distribution and proposals for the amendments to the current legislation needed to transition to incentive-based regulation. However, the Consultant did not take into account the key comments from NEURC to revise the documents, and therefore transitional tariff setting methodology was not finalized. Though the methodologies, regulatory accounting forms and auditing principles were partly developed, NEURC did not approve these documents as legal acts. Achievements under the target assistance with the application of the new transitional methodologies in pilot municipalities are assessed as Low. The new transitional tariff setting methodology and key regulatory documents were not applied in selected pilot municipalities because the methodology was not approved. Despite the overall non-achievement, some positive outcomes were accomplished. As part of the project, NEURC selected pilot municipalities/utilities from Kyiv, Kharkiv, Kamianets-Podilskiy, Kherson, Zhytomyr and Poltava. These municipalities/utilities were involved in the development of transitional tariff setting methodology and key regulatory documents and took part in the Working Group created for this purpose by the NEURC. Throughout the process, however, the utility companies representatives raised their concerns about the new methodology and pointed out the lack of communication and involvement demonstrated by the NEURC. Achievements under the target assistance with the introduction of the sector-wide benchmarking exercise completed by the Regulator were assessed as Low. The sector-wide benchmarking exercise was not completed because NEURC did not adopt the relevant secondary legislation needed for introduction of benchmarking in the district heating (DH) sector. The Consultant prepared and submitted to NEURC a desk study on the best international practices of benchmarking along with developed draft benchmarking methodology and benchmarking manual. These documents were not finalized and accepted by NEURC, because they did not reflect the vision of NEURC on benchmarking model and its main indicators that should be applied to the DH sector. A transition to incentive based tariff regulation remains NEURC’s policy priority, therefore, the developed benchmarking model with relevant changes might be applied in the near future. Several outputs were delivered by the Consultant, although most of these were unsolicited and not specified in the ToR: (i) report on EU Energy Treaty obligations of Ukraine; (ii) proposal for amendments to the current legislation in light of Ukrainian obligations towards EU and Energy Community Treaty; (iii) road map towards implementation of suggested amendments; (iv) legal gap and comparative analysis on best international practices on environmental, renewable energy and energy efficiency policies in selected EU countries; and (v) legal analysis and recommendations for the development of Public-Private Partnerships in the DH sector in Ukraine. The Consultant also developed a two-stage approach that, according to the Consultant, provided a practical way to transition towards incentive-based tariff regulation. This approach was intended to be used either by NEURC, or by Ministry of Regional Development, Construction, Housing and Communal Services (Minregion) (which is responsible for development of a new incentive-based tariff methodology for local authorities). However, as this has been done in a very late stage of Consultant's engagement, was not part of the initial ToR, and was not put into the regulatory context of the NEURC, the value-added of this deliverable was minimal.
